g.text: Do Not Cite, Quote or Distribute
Global coal consumption has been declining, with small fluctuations, since it peaked in 2013
. Coal is faring differently across regions. Coal use has been decreasing in the OECD regions,
particularly in the U.S. and the European Union, while remaining mostly flat in China after a period of
growth, and it is continuing to increase in other
sector, where most coal is being consumed, are similar. Growth
generation capacity in the Asia Pacific region has offset retirements in North America and Europe
Reductions in coal consumption have been driven in large part by non
ons to address air pollution, rapidly declining costs of renewables, and lower
natural gas prices, especially inexpensive unconventional gas in the U.S. (Diluiso et al 2021;
Vinichenko et al., 2021; Culver and Hong 2016). Older coal
environmental regulations or have become unprofitable or uncompetitive have been closed in many
regions. Moreover, coal power expansion has slowed down in Asia, as countries have suspended and
new projects for reasons such as ove
Different regions have replaced retired coal with different energy sources. Old coal fleets have been
replaced approximately half by gas and half by renewables in the U
European Union, and by advanced coal plants and renewables in Asia
coal with new coal facilities is inconsistent with limiting warming to 2ºC or below
(Pfeiffer et al. 2016, 2018; Smith et al. 2019; Tong et al. 2019, Section 6.7
Major coal consuming countries with abundant coal reserves remain far from phasing out coal
. In most developing countries with large coal reserves, coal use has
been increasing to support energy security and because it is perceived to have low
. However, coal faces increasing business risks
from the decreasing costs of alternative, low
emissions energy sources and increasing focus on air
nvironmental impacts from coal mining and use
. Continued coal builds, mostly in developing countries, will increase the risks of stranded assets
(Farfan Orozco 2017; Saygin et al. 2019; Cui et al. 201
Economic, social, and employment impacts of accelerated coal phaseouts tend to be significant in coal
dependent regions. Tailored reemployment has been used to support coal transitions in some regions.
Although some estimates show higher employment
, results vary across regions. Moreover, even with a net increase in total employment, in
the long run, renewable jobs are often located outside of coal regions and require differe
. In a broader sense, achieving a “just transition” also
requires managing the impacts on regional economic development for coal
her energy prices for consumers and energy
Status and Challenges of a Coal Phase
Limiting global warming to 2ºC or below requires a rapid shift away from unabated coal consumption
) in the energy system by 2050 (IPCC 2018a Section 6.7, Chapter 3).
cancellation of new coal power projects and accelerated retirement of existing coal plants
warming to 2ºC or below, and without new builds, existing coal plants will need to retire 10 to 25 years
earlier than the historical average operating lifetime. Completing all planned projects will further reduce
the viable lifetime of all plants
by 5 to 10 years if warming is to be limited to 2ºC or below
